channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Trump Says Golden Dome Missile System to Cost Canada $61 Billion
item.description: President Donald Trump said Canada would need to pay $61 billion to join the “Golden Dome” system he’s proposed to boost missile defense with space-based interceptors.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks on the South Lawn of the White House after arriving on Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, May 25, 2025. Trump said he had “very good” talks with Iranian officials over the weekend on his push to put limits on the Islamic Republic’s nuclear programs.

item.title: Trump’s DHS Asks Supreme Court to Intervene on Deportations
item.description: The Trump administration asked the US Supreme Court to block a judge’s order that requires the government to give people 10 days’ notice and an opportunity to object before they are deported to a so-called third country.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 26, 2024. The US Supreme Court is poised to allow abortions in medical emergencies in Idaho, according to a copy of the opinion that was briefly posted on the court's website.

item.title: UK to Cut Planning Hurdles for Small Builders in Housing Push
item.description: The UK government said it would cut back planning hurdles faced by smaller housebuilders, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks to deliver on his target of building 1.5 million new homes.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: An employee lays bricks on a new build house under construction on a Bellway Plc residential construction site in Bacton, UK, on Friday, Dec. 2, 2022. More than half of Britons planning to buy a home in the next two years said their home-buying plans had either been brought forward or remained unchanged, according to a Bloomberg Intelligence survey.

item.title: Trump to Pardon Stars of Reality Show ‘Chrisley Knows Best’
item.description: President Donald Trump is granting pardons to reality television stars Todd and Julie Chrisley, who were convicted of fraud and tax evasion, the latest offer of clemency to prominent figures accused of white-collar crimes.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: Julie Chrisley and Todd Chrisley on Chrisley Knows Best.

item.title: Portugal Says Carrier TAP Is Strategic as It Plans Privatization
item.description: Portugal said TAP SA is more important for the country’s strategy than as a financial issue, as the government continues planning the privatization of the state-owned airline.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: A TAP SA airplane at the Humberto Delgado Airport in Lisbon, Portugal, on Friday, March 14, 2025. Home prices in Portugal, one of Europe’s hottest property markets, are expected to continue rising in 2025 on the back of increasing foreign demand and lackluster supply, according to DBRS Morningstar.

item.title: US Poised to Receive Golden Share in US Steel-Nippon Tie-Up
item.description: The US government is poised to receive a so-called golden share in United States Steel Corp. as a condition for approving Nippon Steel Corp.’s proposed acquisition of the American company.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: The United States Steel Corp. facility in Clairton, Pennsylvania.

item.title: Thaksin-Backed Coalition Risks Fracturing in Thai Budget Vote
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s less than one-year-old government faces its biggest test yet, with feuding between the two biggest coalition parties threatening the national budget.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra, right, with Anutin Charnvirakul in Bangkok in August 2024.

item.title: Tariff Truce Boosts Consumer Confidence, at Least For Now
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, US economy editor Molly Smith looks at what’s behind the jump in consumer confidence. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Molly Smith

item.title: Trump Escalates Higher Ed Fight With Review of Student Visas
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio ordered US embassies worldwide to stop scheduling interviews for student visas as the Trump administration weighs stricter vetting of applicants’ social-media profiles.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Nick Wadhams, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: Students on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Photographer: Simon Simard/Bloomberg

item.title: Hegseth Imposes Fresh Limits on Reporter Access to the Pentagon
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth imposed a new round of restrictions on news outlets that cover the Pentagon, declaring large portions of the building off-limits to reporters unless they have an escort.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth speaks during a ceremony at the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia.

item.title: Trump Threatens California Funding Halt Over Trans Athletes
item.description: President Donald Trump threatened to withhold federal funding from California, accusing Governor Gavin Newsom of failing to comply with an executive order barring transgender people from competing in women’s sports.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Eliyahu Kamisher

media:content.media:description: The California State Capitol building in Sacramento, California, U.S., on Wednesday, July 7, 2021. California has reinstated a mask mandate for all lawmakers and employees at the state capitol regardless of vaccination status following an outbreak of nine Covid-19 cases there, reported the San Francisco Chronicle.

item.title: NY Wins Order Against US Funding Freeze in Congestion Fight
item.description: New York won a court order temporarily barring the Trump administration from withholding federal approvals or funds for the state’s transportation projects, as the president tries to end Manhattan’s congestion pricing program.
item.dc:creator: Chris Dolmetsch, Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: E-ZPass readers and license plate-scanning cameras over Park Avenue in New York, US, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. The Trump administration is threatening to stop future federal approvals for transportation projects in Manhattan and may withhold funding if New York City's congestion pricing program continues.

item.title: University of California Is Next Target of Trump’s Antisemitism Probe
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration vowed to expand its probes on college campuses beyond Ivy League institutions to other schools — including the University of California system — as the White House’s targeting of higher education intensifies.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Maxwell Adler

media:content.media:description: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators at an encampment on the University of California, Berkeley campus in Berkeley, California, US, on Thursday, April 25, 2024. Campuses across the US have been grappling with pro-Palestinian protests and counter demonstrations since the Oct. 7 attack on Israel by Hamas.

item.title: China Offers to Fund Colombia Projects If the US Blocks Loans
item.description: China could step in to finance infrastructure in Colombia and across Latin America if the US fulfills its threat to block funding, according to Beijing’s ambassador to Bogota.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: The city skyline of Bogota, Colombia, on Sunday, July 3, 2022. Dozens of Venezuelan opposition figures, who turned Colombia into their unofficial headquarters in recent years, say the election of Gustavo Petro as Colombia's first leftist president puts them at risk, and they plan to leave. Photographer: Nathalia Angarita/Bloomberg

item.title: Nigeria’s Tinubu Seeks Approval to Raise $24 Billion in Foreign Loans
item.description: Nigeria’s President Bola Tinubu has requested approval from lawmakers to raise almost $24 billion for an external borrowing plan over the next two years to boost economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Bola Tinubu

item.title: Here Are the Many Ways Trump Is Attacking Harvard
item.description: In its campaign to pressure elite US colleges to make a wide range of policy changes, the administration of President Donald Trump has come down hardest on Harvard University. In what it’s framed as an initiative to fight campus antisemitism and enforce civil rights protections, the administration has frozen more than $2.6 billion in research funding for the Ivy League school, moved to cancel the last remaining $100 million or so in federal contracts, and tried to bar it from enrolling internati
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk through Harvard Yard on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on April 16.

item.title: Trump’s CFTC Pick Discloses $3.4 Million in Assets, Crypto Ties
item.description: Brian Quintenz, the crypto lobbyist President Donald Trump nominated to serve as chair of the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission, disclosed assets worth at least $3.4 million and positions in key industry groups.
item.dc:creator: Nicola M White, Lydia Beyoud, Bill Allison

media:content.media:description: Brian Quintenz, head of policy at a16z Crypto, during the Permissionless II event in Austin, Texas, US, on Monday, Sept. 11, 2023. The conference connects DeFi builders, DAO participants, protocol developers, crypto companies, funds, and institutions at the world's largest DeFi event.

item.title: UK Envoy Urges Transatlantic Tech Alliance, Cites China Threat
item.description: The US and its allies across the Atlantic must forge a technology partnership and win the artificial intelligence race even as China makes steady advances, the UK’s envoy in Washington said.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Peter Mandelson, British Ambassador to the US, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. US President Donald Trump announced a trade framework with the UK, hailing it as a "breakthrough" that will bring down barriers and expand market access for American imports. Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Homeland Chief Noem Backs Nationalist in Poland’s Election
item.description: US Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem urged Poles to vote for the nationalist opposition candidate in Sunday’s presidential election, wading into a tightly-contested campaign that threatens to derail efforts to rebuild the country’s democratic institutions.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski

media:content.media:description: US Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem speaks at CPAC Poland in Rzeszow, Poland, on May 27.

item.title: RFK Jr.’s Cuts to Anti-Tobacco Agencies Slammed by Health Groups
item.description: Recent cutbacks at the Department of Health and Human Services will hurt, or even reverse, decades of progress in reducing the use of addictive tobacco products, more than 80 public health organizations and advocacy groups warned in a letter to Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
item.dc:creator: Fiona Rutherford

media:content.media:description: A person exhales vapor while using an electronic cigarette device in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, Jan. 8, 2020. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said it would ban fruit and mint flavors that have been blamed for getting millions of children hooked on e-cigarettes, a months-in-the-making plan designed to curb an epidemic of underage vaping. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump to End Federal Contracts With Harvard University
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration is moving to cancel all remaining federal contracts with Harvard University, marking the latest escalation of its battle against the oldest and richest US school.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: The Baker Library of the Harvard Business School on the Harvard University campus in Boston, Massachusetts.

item.title: IMF Warns UK to Keep Budget in Check or Risk Market Revolt
item.description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves must stick to her fiscal rules and keep spending under control or risk a market backlash that undermines the government’s economic plans, the International Monetary Fund warned.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves delivers a speech during a reception for UK and EU businesses at Downing Street on May 19.

item.title: BBVA’s Sabadell Bid Delayed Further as Government Starts Review
item.description: Spain’s government decided to conduct its own review of BBVA SA’s bid for rival Banco Sabadell SA, after the country’s antitrust watchdog last month cleared the offer with some conditions.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Zuloaga

media:content.media:description: A BBVA bank branch in Valencia, Spain.

item.title: Texas Lawmakers Require the Ten Commandments in Every Classroom
item.description: Texas lawmakers voted to require public schools to display the Ten Commandments in every classroom, advancing a conservative priority before the end of the state legislature’s session next week.
item.dc:creator: Joe Lovinger

media:content.media:description: A classroom at the Woodson Independent School District school building in Woodson, TX on April 3, 2025.

item.title: Trump Warns Putin ‘Playing With Fire’ as Lawmakers Eye Sanctions
item.description: President Donald Trump warned in a social media post Tuesday that Russian leader Vladimir Putin was “playing with fire”, as the US weighs whether to target Moscow with additional sanctions over its long-range missile and drone barrage against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: MOSCOW, RUSSIA - MAY 22: (RUSSIA OUT) Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks during an awards ceremony at the Saint Yekeaterina's Hall of the Kremlin, May 22, 2025 in Moscow, Russia. Putin gave awards to two dozen Russians during the ceremony, including participants and supporters of the military invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by Contributor/Getty Images)

item.title: Milei Burnishes His Trump Ties by Hosting Health Chief RFK Jr.
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. met President Javier Milei in Buenos Aires, signaling renewed Trump administration support for Argentina with the second trip by a US cabinet secretary in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. met President Javier Milei in Buenos Aires on Tuesday. Source: Office of the Argentine Presidency

item.title: King Charles Delivers Carney's Economic Pledge to Canadian Parliament
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said he intends to lead Canada to “the largest transformation of its economy since the Second World War,” in a speech delivered by King Charles III to open the new parliamentary session.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla take their seats to open the first session of the 45th Parliament of Canada as Mark Carney, left, and Marc Gold, right, look on in the Senate of Canada in Ottawa, on May 27. Photographer: Ben Stansall/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Southeast Asia Leaders Make a Veiled Jab at US Tariff Actions
item.description: Southeast Asian leaders called out unilateral trade actions in a joint statement late Tuesday, without specifically mentioning the US — the region’s largest export customer.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's prime minister, left, and Zafrul Tengku Abdul Aziz, Malaysia's international trade and industry minister, during a news conference at the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. Chinese Premier Li Qiang rallied a group of Southeast Asian and Gulf states to deepen cooperation, as the Asian nation ramps up its charm offensive abroad to counter US efforts to isolate the economy.

item.title: West African Coast Could Boost Revenue for Jihadists, US Warns
item.description: Islamist militants in West Africa could develop new revenue streams if they succeed in reaching the coast, the head of the US military’s Africa Command warned Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Peter Martin

media:content.media:description: A woman walks between shelters and tents at the Wendou 2 IDP displacement camp in Dori, in Burkina Faso, on May 29, 2024.

item.title: US and EU Race for Trade Deal With Six Weeks Left Until Truce Expires
item.description: The European Union and the US signaled a willingness to end a stalemate and work toward a trade deal over the next six weeks, in the first major thaw in their frigid economic relations since President Donald Trump’s second term began in January.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump said he would extend the deadline for the European Union to face 50% tariffs until July 9 after a phone call with Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Bloomberg News Editor News Editor Tony Czuczka shares what we know so far.
